comments.commentBody: I saw another pic, this afternoon. A tragic "footage",showing hundred of migrants crossing farmland on foot, near the Slovenian border. So, we have become able to measure the length of desperation in metric units, using a drone (instrument of war).   There are many ways to look at this tragedy.  I prefer the attempt (emphatic and gentle),to create an illustrated story (narratio, logos).

Hiya, Chef Bea! Between you and Lewis, we now have the Old North State pretty well covered.

I think there's some seeking the asylum of mere modulated moderation.

So the Riis hustle is still being promoted? He was the man who destroyed my neighborhood for a hundred years.

He was a man on the make who discovered that the rich, like Astor and Trinity Church were making money by renting less desirable property to the poor, making them both better off. But he had the enduring insight that comfortable middle class people would both be titillated by reading about and seeing this fact. As a result he could bring social pressure on the rich landlords, which he and many other did. As a result, in 1910, Trinity Church tore down over 100 landmark worthy townhouses in my neighborhood, Hudson Square, and replaced them with factory buildings.

So the (often temporary) poor had lost their housing. Trinity was out of the housing business it had been in for over 100 years. And Jacob Riis became ever more famous. But AFAIK he never helped a single human being or contributed to human progress in any concrete way.

As a result of economic progress over the years, and the housing shortage that 'reformers' have done so much to foster, each of these demolished brownstones would be worth more than $5 million today.

The idea of human progress and the reality are often very, very different.

Thanks for this insightful essay, interview and images about African photography and the Lagos Photo Festival. It's really great to be exposed to new photography and ideas from the African continent. Congratulations to Azu Nwagbogu, Cristina de Middel, all of the photographers involved, and Finbarr O' Reilly.

So well done -- thank you for sharing.   I am moved by this family, by the crisis, and by the commitment of the journalists, photographers, videographers and translators doing this essential and important work.  Thank you, thank you.
This was a very powerful story. It so moved me that I wanted to reach out to the writers and thank them for bringing to light the journey of this family.  I wish there was way to help them.

Long ago, I worked in refugee resettlement because I spoke Russian and identified with Jewish families who longed for freedom to practice their religion.   Even longer ago,  I heard many stories  about the dislocation of stateless peoples wandering about Europe after liberation from the Nazis.  Fast forward to this year, when we Americans read about the hordes of "illegals" who were children in search of a safer haven from the violence in their home countries.  But we had no beautiful photojournalism to accompany the paths these kids took with their coyotes.  We also have very little investigative journalism about the conditions in our own hemisphere that compel so many people to flee. We will be voting fairly soon, and immigration is a big issue here.  Why won't NYT commit resources to highlighting the journey of THESE migrants?  We deserve more information, especially handled with such sensitivity and care.
So glad to know the Majid family made it to Sweden. May their fortitude, perseverance, talents, and decency enrich their new country, and vice versa.
So, in theory, a student with an amazing locker and a 950 on the SAT is going get into  Chicago, which has a 1450  average? I don't think so.
Qcell. I hope your extreme short-sightedness and selfishness is an attempt at humor. If not, it is a clear illustration of the problem our world faces.

Not that I'm any great expert, but the way I see it, we can only solve the climate change problem if we come up with micro-economic policies that happen to achieve the desired macro-economic effect. To me, the reason why most Americans aren't all that concerned about climate change, or won't sacrifice to achieve it, are entirely rooted in their own personal economics. It's easy to support fuel taxes, for instance, if one lives in a place with enough density to take a train to work. Conversely, if one's economic situation dictates that one has to commute 50 miles to work each way, then the idea of raising fuel taxes because it will somehow delay global warming comes off like a kick in the teeth. So it's going to require more than moral scolding to actually do something about this: it will require concrete solutions across the board, and where any sacrifice is so widespread it doesn't seem like a direct hit to a person's wallet. For instance, if we want to cut down car traffic, we'll probably have to build a lot more housing in places (such as expensive suburbs) where zoning restrictions don't generally allow for it.  If we want everyone using power-sipping LED bulbs, we'll have to subsidize it (someone on relief may not find it easy to spend $80 on LED bulbs). Climate change is solvable - but only if most people realize benefits from the policies put in place, as opposed to being force-fed policies that come off as if they'll be the only ones to pay the price for them.

Kirk--so you're cool with mankind going through an apocalypse where some survive. If billions die then maybe the population bomb has in fact happened, and will be lethal. Your point is there will be a catastrophe but because some percentage of humanity will survive it's not that big a deal. Psychopathy?
It didn't thrive without air conditioning.  My father told me that is one of the biggest reasons the South was so far behind the North; before AC there were four months a year you couldn't work.
So what's long with us leading the way? Blaming others and failing to take the moral high ground will not help us save civilization as we know it.
Bill: Your attitude is ruining the planet for our grandchildren. Thanks a lot! Freedom! Yea!
"Academic Facebook." Well stated. Enough already.

So this is essentially academic Facebook? Do we need to construct more shrines to the self?

What about school activities that don't produce projects and reports? Volunteering for, and working with charitable organizations is an amazing activity for young students to be involved in, but how is that going to go into a virtual portfolio?
ah, Pierre. You are so missed. The angels are better fed!
if your medical procedure gets airplay from Entertainment Tonight then go ahead with the incorporation procedures
People recover from hypothermia. They do not recover from being frozen solid.

This reminds me of the case where some people died in a sweat lodge undergoing "therapy"; it can be dangerous to use methodologies which can affect the body's thermal regulation.  She was 24 and interested in "rejuvenation".  Sad commentary on our culture.

What a terribly sad story. I've also heard of people dying in a hot tub. Are these extreme therapies monstrous outgrowths of ice packs and warm baths? If a little is good, is a whole lot supposed to be better? Where is the sense?

I'm sorry. We have regulations to prevent the building of decks that collapse or electrical wiring that burns your house down while you sleep. Most people do not have a PHD. This is why we have government regulations. I am not saying that all government intervention is good. But using the simplistic argument that all is bad makes as much sense as attempting to freeze your pain away. If it is portrayed as a medical treatment than it should be examined and outlawed or regulated or are you arguing that Doctors don't need a license

The myth that "we know best".... yeah, we're all walking around with Ph.Ds in whatever subject we think doesn't need to be regulated including climate change, health and safety, statistics etc....sure.  Having an opinion (especially an anti-regulation opinion usually based on some financial interest) and having thoroughly researched a subject before coming to a conclusion are two very different things.
Charlie.  I think Freethink was being sarcastic and thinks there should be some regulation.

In the linked video, does the white gas look like the gas that sublimates from dry ice?  If so, the carbon dioxide could fairly easily asphyxiate an individual.  Seems dangerous, but no need to regulate the "industry".  No government intervention, please. We know best.
Rolf, it was about the post-imperial British influence in the contemporary world,  not the Raj glory. Thanks.

The "live forever and stay beautiful until you die" industries continue to proliferate, and as Mr. Barnum already told us - there is a sucker born every minute!
The 'treatments' devised over the past twenty years seem to use either ancient concepts - no longer truly understood, or what appear to be space-age technologies not yet fully understood. And they called the folks weirdo freaks who used health stores back in the day!
We have two choices in this life - get older, or not. That is all there is, the rest is snake oil hucksterism.
All this talk of regulation... where are the tea party republicans when you need them!!  : )
"misused the treatment" what an understatement.  The human body is NOT made to sustain that kind of cold for any length of time.

It sounds like some of the stuff I used to see on CSI, set in Las Vegas. They had one episode years ago about an anti-aging clinic and how it was involved in the death of a lady the CSI team was investigating. They need them here because the Nevada OSHA people are saying they have no jurisdiction due to it being after business hours.

These places need to be regulated if an employee can give herself a 'cryobath' and end up like a piece of frozen fish, with nobody else present. For Ms. Ake-Salvacion's friend and colleague to say she misused the treatment is stating the obvious. The lady ended up dead. I'm guessing this 2-store outfit may be shut down after this. One expensive lawsuit could sap their profits.
